newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Ukraine parliament head sees budget passed in May.
newsitem.headline: Ukraine parliament head sees budget passed in May.

text.p: Ukrainian parliamentary speaker Olexander Moroz predicted on Thursday that the much-delayed budget would be approved this month.
"We will have a budget in May," Moroz told deputies who sent back the original 1997 draft in December for amendments.
The document has been stuck in legislative limbo ever since with President Leonid Kuchma blaming the government and government blaming parliament for the delay.
Moroz blamed ministers for working on it too long, saying: "If it had not been for the manipulations and strange activities of the cabinet, then we could have had a budget in December."
Prime Minister Pavlo Lazarenko, repeatedly slammed by Kuchma for delays to the budget, told a news conference on Tuesday that the budget could be approved by May 20.

The budget cannot be passed without new tax laws to underpin it, created by Viktor Pynzenyk, the former deputy prime minister for reforms, who resigned last month in anger saying both sides lacked the political will to pass painful new laws.
The economy ministry says the new draft sets a budget deficit of 5.73 billion hryvnias with gross domestic product forecast at 100.4 billion hryvnias.
Revenues calculated according to new tax laws expected to come into force from July 1 will be 19.95 billion hryvnias and expenditure 25.68 billion hryvnias.
